title: 111_hr6467
content:
The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2010, also known as the "Middle Class Tax Relief Act," makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes provisions for middle-class tax relief, exemptions for high-income individuals, and expensing by small businesses of certain depreciable assets. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2010 includes provisions for expensing by small businesses of certain depreciable assets, extension of alternative minimum tax relief for nonrefundable personal credits, and increased alternative minimum tax exemption amount. PAYGO compliance is also addressed. SEC. 101 of the Middle Class Tax Relief Act makes permanent tax relief for middle-class individuals, including reductions in income tax rates, tax benefits for children, marriage penalty relief, and affordable education provisions. SEC. 102 specifies that certain provisions do not apply to high-income individuals. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act makes permanent tax relief for middle-class individuals, including reductions in income tax rates. The act amends individual income tax rates by adjusting rate brackets and percentages for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act adjusts income tax rates by setting the fourth rate bracket at 33 percent for taxable income below a certain threshold. The 36 percent rate applies to income exceeding that threshold. The term 'applicable amount' refers to the difference between specific dollar amounts. The term 'applicable amount' is defined as the excess of the applicable threshold over the sum of the basic standard deduction and the exemption amount for the taxable year. The applicable threshold is $250,000 for subsection (a). The tax rates for different subsections are as follows: $250,000 for subsection (a), $200,000 for subsections (b) and (c), and half the amount for subsection (d). The term 'fourth rate bracket' refers to the 36-percent rate bracket. An inflation adjustment rule applies for taxable years after 2010. Beginning in calendar years after 2010, there is a phaseout of personal exemptions and itemized deductions. Section 68 is amended to adjust the applicable thresholds and eliminate certain subsections. The phaseout of personal exemptions and itemized deductions begins after 2010. Section 68 is amended to adjust thresholds and remove specific subsections. Subsections (f) and (g) are struck, and deductions for personal exemptions are phased out. Amendments are made to section 151(d) regarding threshold amounts and subparagraphs. The text discusses amendments to tax laws, including the redesignation of subparagraphs and the adjustment for inflation. Additionally, it mentions a reduced rate on capital gains and dividends. The text discusses amendments to tax laws, including a reduced rate on capital gains and dividends. 15 percent of adjusted net capital gain (or taxable income) exceeding a certain amount is taxed, and 20 percent is taxed on the excess amount. Amendments to tax laws include changes to the taxation of dividends and capital gains. The new provisions specify the taxation of qualified dividend income based on taxable income thresholds. Additionally, a maximum tax rate on net capital gains for noncorporate taxpayers is introduced for taxable years beginning after a certain date. For taxable years starting after December 31, 2010, noncorporate taxpayers will be subject to a maximum tax rate on net capital gains. This rate includes 15% of adjusted net capital gain exceeding a certain amount, and 20% of any excess amount beyond that. Amendments have been made to change the tax rate from 15% to 20% in certain provisions. Amendments have been made to change the tax rate from 15% to 20% in certain provisions for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. Amendments to change the tax rate from 15% to 20% for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. Withholding amendments apply to amounts paid on or after January 1, 2011. SEC. 103. RELATED AMENDMENTS. SEC. 103. RELATED AMENDMENTS.

(a) Application of Increase in Refundable Portion of Child Tax Credit.--Subsection (d) of section 24 is amended by changing the amount from $10,000 to $3,000 and removing paragraphs (3) and (4). These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.

(b) Application of Increase in Earned Income Tax Credit.--Section 32(b)(2)(B) is amended for joint returns filed by eligible individuals and their spouses regarding the phaseout amount. The $5,000 amount in clause (i) shall be increased for taxable years after 2010 based on the cost of living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3). The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section do not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. Increased limitations on expensing by small businesses of certain depreciable assets under Title II. Increased limitations on expensing by small businesses of certain depreciable assets under Title II. Amendments include raising the dollar limitation to $125,000 and the threshold for phaseout to $500,000, with inflation adjustments applied annually. The taxable year begins in calendar year 2006, with rounding rules for dollar and phaseout limitations. Additionally, the authority to revoke an election is made permanent. The authority to revoke an election made permanent for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. Extension of Alternative Minimum Tax Relief for Nonrefundable Personal Credits from 2000 to 2011 and Increased Alternative Minimum Tax Exemption Amount. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 302 extends the increased alternative minimum tax exemption amount for taxable years beginning in 2010 or 2011. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. TITLE IV--BUDGETARY PROVISION

SEC. 401. PAYGO COMPLIANCE.

The budgetary effects of this Act, for complying with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, shall be determined by reference to the latest statement titled "Budgetary Effects of PAYGO Legislation" for this Act, submitted for printing in the Congressional Record by the Chairman of the House Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
